exiftool.ImageFileCharacteristics: Executable, No line numbers, No symbols, Bytes reversed lo, 32-bit, Bytes reversed hi

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Detects malware by known bad imphash or rich_pe_header_hash
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: Arnim Rupp

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Shadow Copies Deletion Using Operating Systems Utilities
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Shadow Copies deletion using operating systems utilities
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems), Michael Haag, Teymur Kheirkhabarov, Daniil Yugoslavskiy, oscd.community, Andreas Hunkeler (@Karneades)

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Credential Manager Access By Uncommon Applications
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Detects suspicious processes based on name and location that access the windows credential manager and vault.
Which can be a sign of credential stealing. Example case would be usage of mimikatz "dpapi::cred" function

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Files With System Process Name In Unsuspected Locations
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Detects the creation of an executable with a system process name in folders other than the system ones (System32, SysWOW64, etc.).
It is highly recommended to perform an initial baseline before using this rule in production.
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Sander Wiebing, Tim Shelton, Nasreddine Bencherchali (Nextron Systems)

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Access To Windows DPAPI Master Keys By Uncommon Applications
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Detects file access requests to the the Windows Data Protection API Master keys by an uncommon application.
This can be a sign of credential stealing. Example case would be usage of mimikatz "dpapi::masterkey" function

threat_severity.level_description: Severity HIGH because it was considered virus. Other contributing factor was that it could not be run in sandboxes.

attributes.magic: PE32 executable (GUI) Intel 80386, for MS Windows
